FNight of the Operatic Melo-drame
ASI) POSITIVELY THE
Last Night of the Horses this Season*
Benefit of Mr* Norman*
MONDAY, Jan. 31st, 1825,
MR. N. has the honor to inform his Friends find the Public that the Proprietor has most liberally allowed Tom the First Performance of that highlv-poptilar, Serio-Melo Dramatic Operatic Romance, of peculiar and terrific interest, which it us been some time in preparation, CALLED
Presumption ■
___	________________OR, THE	W
Fate of Frankenstein!
With the Original Music by Mr. Watson, of the Theatre Royal, Covent-Garrlen—-end additional I vcnl Music by Mr. A. I as.— the Scenery by Mr. Whitmorf—7 he Machinery by Mr. Sieiiman—THE PIECE ARRANGED AND PRODUCED UNDER THE DIRECTION Oft' AIU. NORMAN “ The event on which this fiction is founded has been supposed, by Dtl. Darwin, and some of the Physiological writers of Germany, as not of impossible occurrence ...I shall not be supposed ns according thp remotest degree of serious faith to such an imagination ; yet. in assuming it as the basis of a work of fancy, l have not considered myself as merely weaving a senes of supernatural terrors. Tin event on which the interest of the story depends is exempt from the disadvantages of u mere tale of spectres or enchantment; it was recommended by the novelty of the situation which it developes ; and however impossible as a physical fact, affords a point of view to the imagination, for the delineating of the human passions, more comprehensive and commanding than any which the ordinary relations of existing events can yield.’’	From the Preface to the Novel of Frankenstein.
tO" The striking noi ai eihibHed in this Story, is the fatal consequence oj that presumption vhkh attempts to penetrate, beyond prescribed depths} into the mysteries of nature.

PRES UJUP TIO.Y:
Or, The Fate of Frankenstein !
** The event on which this fiction is founded has beet» Supposed, by Dr. Darwin, and some of the Physiol ogical writers of Germany, as not of impossible occurrence ...I shall not be supposed as according the remotest degree of serious faith to such an imagination ; yet, in assuming it as the basis of a work of fancy, I have not considered myself as merely weaving a series of supernatural terrors. The event on which the interest of the story depends is exempt from the disadvantages of a mere tale of spectres or enchantment; it was recommended by the novelty of the situation which it developes ; and however impossible as a physical fact, affords a point of view to the imagination, for the delineating of the human passions, more comprehensive and commanding than any which the ordinary relations of existing events can yield."	From the Preface to the Novel of Frankenstein.

PRESUJUP TIOJV:
Or, The Fate of Frankenstein!
« The event on which this fiction is founded has been supposed, by Dr. Darwin, and some of tb, Physiological writers of Germany, as not of impossible occurrence ...I shall not be supposed as according the remotest degree of serious faith to sncn an imagination ; yet, in assuming it as the basis of a work of fancy, l have not considered myself as merely weaving a series of supernatural terrors. The tvent on which the interest of the story depends is exempt from the disadvantages of a mere tale of spectres or enchantment; it was recommended by the novelty of the situation which it developes ; and however impossible as a physical fact, affords a point of view to the imagination, for the delineating of the human passions, more comprehensive and commanding than any which the ordinary relations of existing events can yield.”___From the Preface to the Novel of Frankenstein.

~	“ ANEW MUSICAL PERFORMANCE,
Of »n EXTRAORDINARY CHARACTER is m Active Preparation, and will speedily be produced called
Oer Freischutz ; or, the Seventh Bullet T
This eccentric vehicle for Music and Scenic effect is a literal translation from the highly celebrated German Opera composed by Carl Maria Von Weber, fok which considerable additions
to the Orchestra are Engaged.

A New Musical Performance, of an extraordinary character,
Is in active preparation, and will positively he produced on Thursdav next, called
Der Freischutz, or the Seventh Bullet.
(In which Mr. PHILIPPS, Mist FORDE, and Mitt HARVEY will appear.)
This eccentric vehicle for Music and Scenic effect is a literal translation from the highly celebrated German Opera composed by Carl Marta Von WehEr, to give effect to which there are considerable additions to the Orchestra and Vocal department.

At No. I . .(Repeated by the echoes) Eclipse of the Moon commences... NightBirds, Bats, and various winged monsters appear.	-
It No. 2....The Witch of the Glen, and various Reptiles, viz. enormous Toads, Lizards, Guanas, Spit-fires, Snakes, Fire, Hies, Sec. appear ... Eclipse nearly passed over the Moon.
At No. A....A Storm and Hurricane, the Moon, becomes Red, and the Torrent changes to Blood ...a Boa-Constrictor Serpent crosses the Glen.
At No i_'I he rattle of Wheels, and tramp of Horses are heard, and a
Colossal Skeleton Passes through the Gfcn on a Fiery Chariot
At So. 5....Neighing and Barking heard amid discordant & eccentric Music, supposed to accompany
THE WILD CHASE IN THE AIR!!
The misty forms of skeleton Stag, Horses, Horsemen, and Hounds pass over tire Magic Circle in the Clouds to a Hunting Chorus of Invisible ¡Spirits.
At No. 6 .. A tremendous storm of Thunder', Lightning and Hail....the Earth becomes convulsed ... Vampires thrust their their half-decayed bodies from the Rocks, Earth, Sic. .at this instant the
Tree# are torn up by the root#, and an Earthquake take# place.
and all the horrors of the preceding numbers are accumulated in order to drive the Fteischulz from
THE MAGIC CIRCLE.
At N*. 7 In addition to, the proceeding terrors, a Thunder Bolt rends a Rock, and
ZA^IIEL appears on a FIERY Throne!!!
Snrroundediby Ftredrakes, Griffins, 8tc. ...and the Scene closes	a

THIe WILD CHASE IN THE AIR!!

and all the horrors of the preceding numbers are accumulated in order to drive the Freischütz from

THE CASTING OF THE BALLS.
At No. 1 ..(Repealed by the echoes) Eclipse of the Moon commences .. NigUtBirds, Buts, and , various winged monsters appear.
\t No. 2....The Witch of the Glen, and various Reptiles, viz. enormous Toads, Lizards, Guanas, Spit-fires, Snakes, Fire, Flies, See. appear....Eclipse nearly passed over the Moon.
At No. 8.... A ¡■"term and Hurricane, the Moon becomes Hed, and the Torrent changes io lttood ..ex, Boa-Constrictor Serpent crosses-the G4en.
At No 4....1 be rattle of Wheels, and tramp of Horses are heard, and a
Colossal Skeleton Passes through the Glen on a Fiery Chariot
At No. ¿....Neighing and Barking heard amid discordant k eccentric Music, supposed to accompany
THE WILD CHASE IN THE AIR!I
The misty forms of Skeleton Stag, Horses, Horsemen, and Hounds pass over the Magic Circle in the ■Clouds to a Hunting Lhartm of Invisible Spirits.	v
At No. 6 .. A tremendous storm of Thunder, Lightning and Hail....the Farth becomes convulsed ... Vampires thrust their Imlf-decayed bodies froth the Rocks, Earth, See.at this rnstmrt the
'Frees are torn up by the roots, and an Earthquake takes place,
and all the horrors of the preceding numbers are accumulated in order to drive the Fieisckut: from
THE MAGIC CIRCLE.
At No 7 ...In addition to the proceeding terrors, a Thunder Bolt rends a Rock, «ml
ZAMIEIj appears on a FIERY Throne!!!
Surrounded by Firedraket, G rdSws, Stc.. and the Scene closes

After which, will he performed, 2<1 time, a New Melo-Drnme, in 3 act«, called The
Courier of Naples,
The leading Incident in thin Melo-Drame turn, upon a melancholy fact, which occurred in Prance, during the reign of Napoleon. A Robbery ami Murder of the most atrocious nature was committed l>v three accomplice»,-—two were taken, and the third escaped. A person, totally innocent, was arrested on strong suspicion—the most powerful evidence was produced against him—he was tried, condemned, and executed, with the other fwo. Stonily after, the real culprit was discovered,—and there is at this time, an Application pending in the I'renrh Courts, I'fom the family qf the unfortunate victim, for the restoration of Ins property, whir h had hero confiscated.

Miss TORDE has been seized with a severe Chest attack, which confines her to her bed, andfor which
it is necessary she should lose blood--she is guile too ill to play to-morrow and altogether too hoarse to attempt
to sing.

FOR THE BENEFIT OF MR.
Who embraces this opportunity of expressing his regret, that the peculiar regulations Of the Theatre this Season have prevented him the Honor of appearing before a Generous and Enlightened Public more frequently; on honor rendered more desirable from the flattering and distinguished receptions which he experienced so liberally at the commencement of the Season, and Which he begs leave most respectfully and gratefully to acknowledge.	__
ON MONDAY, *i^«F MAY,
Will be Acted, (F<nsi' time th's Season), the Admired Play of
fTitUamTeU,
THE HERO OF SWITZERLAND.
Gesler,............Mr. MATHEWS,
............Mr. BARRY, «truth............Mr. WILLIAMS, Rodolph,..........Mr. SMO&LBT,
" Uutolti.......Mr. O’ROURKE, Oeratd..........Mr. GLOVER, Braun.........Mr. JOHNSON,
William Tell,................ .Mr. SALTER,	,
Albert, (his Sod)......Mias YATES, Melchtal,................Mr, CUNNINGHAM,
Kml.„.........Mr. DIGGES, Flint,...........Mr. FORDE, Voider,..............Mr FREDERICKS,
* Wald man,..........Mr. CHIPPENDALE, Michael,.................Mr TALBOT, .
- JoEheli.................Mr. B. HILL,	Pierre,...,............Mr. CARROLL,
f Theodore..................Mr. HAMERTON,	Savoyard,...........Miss CRAWFORD
■	Emma,(Tell,8 Wife)............Miss LACY.
